title: Thug smashes up ambulance with concrete slab for no reason as he is filmed by stunned paramedics
text:
News Thug smashes up ambulance with concrete slab for no reason as he is filmed by stunned paramedics Thug Josh Thacker, 24, caused £3,500 worth of damage and put the ambulance out of action for six days as he punched and kicked the passenger side wing mirror Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Yob filmed hurling concrete slab through AMBULANCE window Share this video Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A shocked ambulance crew filmed from a patient's window as a violent thug smashed their ambulance with a concrete slab. 
But despite causing £3,500 worth of damage and putting the ambulance out of action for six days, yob Josh Thacker escaped jail. 
East Midlands Ambulance Service paramedics were called to treat a person in Leicester on the evening of January 18. 
While inside the house they heard shouting and, realising the ambulance was being damaged, whipped out a mobile phone to record the attack. 
Thacker, 24, smashed the front windscreen of their ambulance with a concrete slab and punched and kicked the passenger side wing mirror. Read More Mum releases shocking pictures of 16-year-old schoolboy left for dead with smashed skull by 'two kids aged 11-12' (Photo: West midlands ambulance service) 
Thacker, of Leicester, pleaded guilty to three separate incidents relating to criminal damage at the city's magistrates court on Thursday. 
He was handed an 18-month community order and told to pay £50 compensation, but escaped a jail sentence. 
In the video footage , the paramedics can be heard reporting the damage to their control centre. 
The controller asks: "Sorry he's throwing what at the ambulance?" 
The paramedic responds: "Slabs, and now he's punching the window and kicking the ambulance." (Photo: West midlands ambulance service) 
Mark Gregory, General Manager for EMAS in Leicestershire, said: "I once again find myself saddened and appalled by the mindless actions of an individual. 
"Our staff work hard every day to deliver the best possible care to the public we serve. 
"Actions like this make their job even harder, not to mention the anxiety they and the patient must have experienced during this attack. 
"The money spent on these repairs could have been spent on extra crews and lifesaving equipment. Read More Violent bully with 'not guilty' tattoo on his arm jailed for brutally attacking woman who owed him £20 
"However, because of the actions of one individual we will now be prevented from that. 
"I again urge the public to treat all NHS staff with respect. Abuse of staff will not be tolerated and we will pursue the maximum penalty where this is breached." (Photo: West midlands ambulance service) 
East Midlands Ambulance Service has been under heavy pressure over the winter period, and it has seen an increase in the number of incidents of criminal damage. 
In January, an ambulance crew was unable to get to a rugby player with a dislocated knee just two miles from Leicester Royal Infirmary. His teammates were forced to take him on a trestle table in the back of a pickup vehicle. 
In a previous attack on an ambulance, a wheelie bin of rubbish was tipped into an ambulance cab while a patient was being treated in the vehicle. Like us on Facebook
